He is a battleground of conflicting desires, of opposing interests, of warring emotions. On one side, the desire for gain, the instinct of self-preservation, the fear of loss, the dread of failure; on the other, the impulse of generosity, the sense of justice, the feeling of responsibility, the wish to do good. And between these two opposing forces, the business man is torn, often with little chance of escape, and with no clear guide to follow. His decision, when it comes, is likely to be the result of a compromise, a balancing of the conflicting forces, rather than a clear-cut choice between right and wrong. And so, the business man, far from being the cold, calculating machine he is often supposed to be, is in reality a complex, many-sided human being, subject to all the weaknesses and frailties of humanity.
